Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Light Emitting Diode-based Smart Cue
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in its capability to promote the safety of people with dementia. According to research, 70% of people with dementia will wander, which can result in a difficult experience for both missing people and care givers. The demand for protecting and recovering missing people with dementia has been increased over the past decades. Advancement of this tracking system has the potential for enhancing their safety and giving a peace of mind to care givers without compromising the effectiveness. The core set of methods and processes of the technology has the potential to be replicated, adapted and used in other crowd sensing applications globally. Even before the care givers notice, the "crowd" can potentially be able to help.

This I-Corps project is focused on technology to improve the tracking, and protecting paradigm of using mobile devices carried by the people with dementia as well as will also explore the commercial potential of an intelligent tracking system. This innovative system, LED-based Smart Cue (LESQ), can monitor the status of the wearer in addition to tracking the location. If an abnormal condition is detected, the LESQ system can ask for immediate help. If the wearer carries a smartphone, the LESQ system can send an alert message directly to the care giver. One important feature of the LESQ system is to improve the self-diagnosis of the potential for wandering by the people with dementia. A smart tag tracks the wearer's status by using the timer and gaits, in addition to the geo-location. Implementation of the cost and power efficient, lightweight, and flexible system may significantly improve the usability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The geo-tracking and geo-zoning paradigm of using mobile devices carried by humans for a collaborative objective are not new. However, the transformative concept of this project, LED-based Smart Cue (LESQ), is to build a public safety system that enables early warning signs directly from the Vulnerable Missing Persons/Pets (VMP) itself and brings the power of the crowd to help immediately. Even before the caregiver or VMP realizes the loss, the crowd will be able to inform and help.

LESQ can reduce device costs as well as improve usability. As presented in Figure 1, LESQ consists of a smart tag (BLE, GPS, an inertial measurement unit (IMU), and a rechargeable battery), an LED light strip, and a smartphone application. LESQ is a small waterproof form factor that can be harnessed as a shoe rim attachment, shoe clip, shoestring, extra shoe cover, collar, wristband, walking cane, etc. A smart tag tracks the VMP’s status by monitoring the timer, gaits, and location. If a VMP is in an abnormal condition, LESQ starts blinking its LED light to ask for help from nearby people as well as sends a BLE beacon alert to the caregivers (if the VMP carries a smartphone). A smartphone app can flexibly configure each VMP’s statusmonitoring condition.

We are interested in an essential issue of societal safety. Finding any missing or wandering person will be an enormous societal impact. LESQ gives peace of mind to caregivers by tracking VMP quickly. The results of our experiments gave us several new insights into how to improve the technologies for helping societal safety. The core set of methods and processes of the project can be replicated, adapted, and used in other crowdsensing applications in smart and connected communities. Besides, we learned how to carry out the customer discovery process through personal interviews and create a compelling business model canvas to move forward the commercialization efforts.
